extendedIngredients.name: dairy milk
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 cup non dairy milk (I used So Delicious Coconut Milk)

extendedIngredients.name: flax meal
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 tablespoon chia meal. If using flax meal, use 4 teaspoons meal and set aside to gel) OR 1 egg

extendedIngredients.name: half & half
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tablespoons maple syrup, honey, or replace up to half with equivalent in stevia liquid

extendedIngredients.name: light olive oil
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 tablespoons melted coconut oil or light olive oil

extendedIngredients.name: teff flour
extendedIngredients.originalString: ½ cup teff flour (you can use brown rice if you don't have it)
metaInformation: (you can use brown rice if you don't have it)

extendedIngredients.name: vanilla extract
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 teaspoon vanilla extract OR powder (you could add more to really up the vanilla oompf!)
metaInformation: (you could add more to really up the vanilla oompf!)

recipes.title: Gluten Free-Vegan Pumpkin Pancakes
recipes.instructions: Whisk the wet ingredients together and set aside.In a large bowl, whisk the dry ingredients.Make a well in the center of the dry mix and add all the wet ingredients. Whisk the wet ingredients gently to mix, then continue to incorporate the flour mix. Batter will be a typical pancake batter. The moisture content of the pumpkin puree will effect the final viscosity of the batter, so add a few tablespoons of flour or water as needed.Pour batter into 3-4" circles in a preheated pan greased with oil or butter. I usually am just about medium heat. When you see little bubbles work their way to the top, it is time to flip and cook the other side.

steps.step: Whisk the wet ingredients together and set aside.In a large bowl, whisk the dry ingredients.Make a well in the center of the dry mix and add all the wet ingredients.

Whisk the wet ingredients gently to mix, then continue to incorporate the flour mix. Batter will be a typical pancake batter. The moisture content of the pumpkin puree will effect the final viscosity of the batter, so add a few tablespoons of flour or water as needed.

Pour batter into 3-4" circles in a preheated pan greased with oil or butter. I usually am just about medium heat. When you see little bubbles work their way to the top, it is time to flip and cook the other side.
